quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Dictionaries[/h1]

[b]Dictionaries [/b]are data structures used to map arbitrary keys to values. 
Lists can be thought of as dictionaries with integer keys within a certain range.
Dictionaries can be indexed in the same way as lists, using [b]square brackets[/b] containing keys.
[b]Example:[/b] [code format="py" codeId="359"]ages = {"Dave": 24, "Mary": 42, "John": 58}
print(ages["Dave"])
print(ages["Mary"])[/code]
[b]Result:[/b] [code format="raw" ]>>>
24
42
>>>[/code]
[note]Each element in a dictionary is represented by a [b]key:value[/b] pair.[/note]

[h1]Dictionaries[/h1]

Trying to index a key that isn't part of the dictionary returns a [b]KeyError[/b].
[b]Example:[/b] [code format="py" codeId="360"]primary = {
  "red": [255, 0, 0], 
  "green": [0, 255, 0], 
  "blue": [0, 0, 255], 
}

print(primary["red"])
print(primary["yellow"])[/code]
[b]Result:[/b] [code format="raw" ]>>>
[255, 0, 0]

[b]KeyError: 'yellow'[/b]
>>>[/code]
As you can see, a dictionary can store any types of data as values.
[note]An empty dictionary is defined as [b]{}[/b].[/note]

quizzes.question: Which of these values can't be used as a dictionary key?
quizzes.textContent:
[h2]Dictionaries[/h2]

Only [b]immutable [/b]objects can be used as keys to dictionaries. [b]Immutable [/b]objects are those that can't be changed. So far, the only mutable objects you've come across are [b]lists [/b]and [b]dictionaries[/b]. Trying to use a mutable object as a dictionary key causes a [b]TypeError[/b]. [code format="py" codeId="361"]bad_dict = {
  [1, 2, 3]: "one two three", 
}[/code]
[b]Result:[/b] [code format="raw" ]>>>
TypeError: unhashable type: 'list'
>>>[/code]
